identificationModule.briefTitle: The Effect of tDCS on Motor Learning and Neural Network in Stroke Patients
identificationModule.officialTitle: Investigation of Compensational Mechanism and Effect of Transcranial Direct Stimulation on Motor Learning Through Neural Network Analysis in Stroke Patients

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study is to investigate the effect of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) simulation on motor learning to stroke patients compared to sham stimulation

armGroups.label: Real stimulation before motor learning training
armGroups.description: Patients receive five sessions of tDCS stimulation over C3 (patient with left-sided lesion) or C4 (patient with right-sided lesion) based on 10-20 system immediately before sequential finger tapping task.

armGroups.label: Sham stimulation before motor learning training
armGroups.description: Patients receive five sessions of sham stimulation over C3 (patient with left-sided lesion) or C4 (patient with right-sided lesion) based on 10-20 system immediately before sequential finger tapping task.

interventions.name: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation
interventions.description: Transcranial direct current stimulation is a form of noninvasive neuromodulation that uses constant and low direct current delivered via electrodes on the scalp.
armGroupLabels: Real stimulation before motor learning training

interventions.name: Motor learning
interventions.description: Sequential finger tapping task training is applied to stroke patients.

primaryOutcomes.description: The score is a stroke-specific, performance-based impairment index. The degree of impairment of upper and lower limbs is measured.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in cortical activity using fNIRS signals during brain stimulation
secondaryOutcomes.description: Cortical activities before, during and after brain stimulation sessions are compared.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, during, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions

secondaryOutcomes.description: Resting motor threshold (rMT) and amplitude of motor evoked potential in first dorsal interosseous muscle are measured. These outcomes are measured by transcranial magnetic stimulation over the motor hotspot. The rMT is defined as the minimum stimulus intensity that produced a minimal motor evoked response at rest. The amplitude means peak to peak of the muscle response.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, immediately after five brain stimulation sessions

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Unilateral stroke including basal ganglia lesion patients
* Chronic patients over 6 months after onset
* Patients with the movement of fingers

Exclusion Criteria:

* History of psychiatric disease
* Significant other neurological diseases except for stroke
* Difficult to perform this experiment
* Patients who are deemed difficult to participate in this research by the investigator
* Patients with metal implants and medical devices
* History of epilepsy
* Pregnancy
* Skin defect at the site of electrode attachment
